newsitem.title: USA: Ford sees Q2 gain from Hertz, charge from plants.
newsitem.headline: Ford sees Q2 gain from Hertz, charge from plants.

text.p: Ford Motor Co expects to record a 1997 second quarter gain from the April initial public offering of an 18.5 percent stake in Hertz Corp, according to a quarterly filing by Ford with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday.
The amount of the gain was not specified.

The initial public offering of 17.4 million shares raised more than $400 million for Hertz. Substantially all of the net proceeds from the offering was used to reduce short term debt (commercial paper) of Hertz, the filing said.
Hertz had increased its outstanding commercial paper to repay a $460 million intercompany debt owed to Ford, the filing said.

In another development during the 1997 first quarter, Ford announced several changes at its plants worldwide which will result in a one-time charge in the second quarter, according to the filing. The amount was not specified.

These changes include eliminating a shift at its Halewood plant in the United Kingdom and idling a passenger car system at its Lorain, Ohio assembly plant. In addition, in Brazil, two foundries and an engine plant were closed and its Ipiranga truck plant was downsized.
Ford also discontinued certain vehicle models including the Ford Aspire, Probe, Thunderbird, Aerostar and Mercury Cougar.
